isis.stitle: AIR CONDITIONING COMPRESSOR AND CLUTCH, TWO CYLINDER RECIPROCATING TYPE - After 01/01/1993 (R-134a)

svcsection.title: AIR CONDITIONING COMPRESSOR AND CLUTCH, TWO CYLINDER RECIPROCATING TYPE - After 01/01/1993 (R-134a)

lev1.title: SERVICE TIPS
lev1.para: The majority of compressor parts are made up of aluminum alloys and care must be taken in handling not to mar, nick or scratch. All machined surfaces must be free of nicks and burrs to insure proper fit and gasket seating. When replacing parts and securing with bolts or capscrews, the specified torque requirements found in the TORQUE CHART should never be exceeded. Bolts should all be run in until the bolt heads make contact, then tightened with a torque wrench in a sequence resulting in tightening of diagonally opposite bolts until all are drawn up to specified torques.

An important factor in compressor servicing is cleanliness and care should be exercised to prevent dirt or foreign material from entering the compressor when it is opened. All old gaskets should be removed and replaced. All gasket surfaces should be clean and all parts to be reused should be washed in a suitable petroleum base solvent. Before assembly to the compressor, all gaskets should be dipped in clean mineral oil.

Gaskets are made of a neoprene composition fiber and wicking action will result as oil follows the fiber. Do not mistake this wicking action for leaking. Wicking is a normal condition and is to be expected.
Do not use refrigerant oil to lubricate O-rings, gaskets or seals. Use only mineral oil to lubricate these items.

lev1.title: COMPRESSOR
lev1.para: The compressor is a two-cylinder reciprocating unit ( Figure 1). It is belt driven through a magnetic clutch located on the compressor crankshaft.

calloutgroup.callout1: 3. PORT CAPS (KEEP IN PLACE WHEN LINES ARE DISCONNECTED)

lev1.para: The functions of the compressor are to push the refrigerant through the air conditioning system, and compress and superheat the heat-saturated refrigerant returned from the evaporator.

The compressor crankcase, cylinder head, pistons, connecting rods, bearing housing, valve plate and base plate are die cast aluminum. The crankshaft is cast iron as are the cylinder liners, which are permanently cast into the crankcase.

A splash lubrication system provides lubrication to the front and rear crankshaft bearings, connecting rods and cylinder walls. The existing pressure differential between the suction intake and the crankcase provides lubricating oil to the front shaft seal. An oil plug on each side of the crankcase permits oil checking regardless of compressor mounting.

With the introduction of R-134A refrigerant, the high pressure relief valve is moved from the receiver-dryer to the compressor on production vehicles ( Figure 1). Replacement receiver-dryers will have a pressure relief valve.

lev1.title: MAGNETIC CLUTCH
lev1.para: The compressor magnetic clutch is secured to the compressor crankshaft ( Figure 2). The purpose of the clutch is to engage and disengage the belt drive as necessary to maintain desired interior cab temperature.

The primary components of the clutch are: the pulley assembly, which contains the clutch disc and bearing and is mounted on the crankshaft, and the stationary field coil, mounted on the compressor housing ( Figure 2).
